segments.text: Hello and welcome to Rising.
Happy Friday everybody.
We have a great show for you today.
I'm joined this Friday by Amber Athery.
Amber, it's a solid news day.
There's not really much going on.
Sure, apocalyptic sky, former president, and died in all very normal.
Former president Donald Trump wasn't he'd indicted for a second time yesterday related
to his handling of classified documents after his term in office.
Trump's lawyer confirmed he's facing seven counts, including charges under the Espionage
Act, obstruction of justice, destruction or falsification of records, conspiracy, and
false statements.
The former president shared this video online after news of his indictment.
Let's watch.
Very sadly, we're a nation of decline.
And yet, they go after a popular president, a president that got more votes than any sitting
president in the history of our country by far and did much better the second time in
the election than the first.
And they go after him on a box his hooks, just like the Russia, Russia, Russia, hooks,
and all of the others, it's just been going on for seven years, that they can't stop because
it's election interference at the highest level.
There's never been anything like what's happened.
I'm an innocent man.
I'm an innocent person.
They had the Mueller hooks, the Mueller report, and that came out no collusion after two
and a half years.
That was set up by Hillary Clinton and Democrats, but this is what they do.
This is what they do so well.
If they would devote their energies to honesty and integrity, it would be a lot better for
our country.
They could do a lot better.
They could do a lot of great things.
Here to discuss this with us today is the Hills Rebecca Bich.
Welcome, Rebecca.
Glad to have you on to break this down.
Yeah, thanks for having me.
Good morning.
Good morning.
So what do we make of this?
Is he comparing apples to oranges here with comparing his indictment with maybe, I don't
know, the documents that Pence had, the documents that Hillary had.
For me, when I look at this, I think, OK, well, Trump refused to give them back.
He tried to hide them.
Seems like a different scenario than what he described saying that this is just politically
motivated.
What do you make of his statement there?
Yeah, I mean, this is absolutely not an apples to apples comparison.
Just the amount of documents that were found, you know, both with Pence or with Biden compared
to the at least 300 classified records that Trump had at Mar-a-Lago would distinguish
that just on numbers alone.
But of course, when we see these charges, another major distinction here is the obstruction
of justice charges.
And it's clear from the pattern of the case and what was detailed on the warrant to search
the property that they made multiple efforts to recover these documents and were unable
to do so.
And that's what distinguishes this case in a major way from both Pence and Biden.
And I would note that the Justice Department just decided not to proceed in charging Trump
in relation, or I'm sorry, in charging Pence for the documents that were found among his
belongings.
Where does the fact that Trump says that he declassified these documents come into play
here?
Because his argument about the Biden document scandal is that Biden was a senator at the
time that he took a lot of these documents and therefore didn't have the capability or
the authority to declassify, whereas he did.
Is there any evidence to suggest that he did go through the property classification process,
or is that kind of why the indictment has proceeded?
So one of the things that's important to note here too is that for espionage act charges,
themselves don't have to be classified.
They just have to be considered what's called national defense information.
That's important because this law was written before the US even had a classification system.
But separately from that, I'm sorry, can you repeat the original question?
Sure, I'm just wondering if there's any evidence to suggest that Trump did declassify some
of these documents.
Him and his administration officials claimed that he basically had a standing order to
declassify everything that left the White House.
So I'm wondering where that plays into the indictment.
Yeah, that's right.
Sorry, let's jump back into that claim.
So another thing that's huge on this front is reporting by CNN indicating that there's
a recording of Trump kind of spelling out that he both has classified records and that he
would be unable to show it to the people that he's speaking with during this meeting because
it's classified.
He didn't declassify it before leaving office.
That's another thing that's important for an espionage act charge because you have to
show that there was a willful retention.
But that admission on tape, which appears to be evidence that the special counsel has
in his possession, would indicate that Trump understood that some of these documents were
classified, that he couldn't be showing them to people, couldn't be releasing them.
But separately, Trump has claimed that, that he can just declassify a record just
by thinking about it.
That's not exactly how this works.
Presidents do have broad power to declassify records, but there is a process that results
from declassifying a record.
So there would in theory be some kind of record keeping around that.
But I'd also like to note that while Trump has said that publicly, that's not a claim
that his lawyers have specifically made in court filings.
They have not backed that up in their own legal arguments in court.
Something I say a lot is that the law and justice are not the same.
I find that it's important to make that distinction sure, yes, it's legal.
There's a technical classification process.
It's a legal term to say documents classified.
But there's also a reason for that.
And there's a process that Trump would have to go through, right, where he would meet
with folks who would explain what are the threats to national security.
If we were to declassify these documents, and that's why there's a process there to
declassify them.
Although he does have the power to make documents declassified as the president, him just saying
these are declassified now, doesn't suffice and we have this process for a reason.
Can you say anything more about the importance of the declassification process?
Yes, so like you pointed out, this isn't something that a president can do after leaving
office.
It is only something that they can do while they are in back to president.
So the timeline of these documents being moved is kind of key here.
But separately from that, a president does have the power to declassify records.
But keep in mind that there's a whole cohort of people who have accessed this information
but are also responsible for properly storing it.
And so when a president does declassify a record, that notice goes out to a bunch of
people who then have to reconsider how it's stored, how it's classified, just basically
how it's managed within the government.
What do you make of the Espionage Act being used here?
This is a World War I era law that was basically used against perceived enemies of the state.
In terms of the political calculus of this, how does using the Espionage Act in particular
play into the perception that this could be a political prosecution?
Well, you know, I think obviously it's very remarkable that he's being charged with that.
I mean, to have a former president be charged under the Espionage Act is like extraordinary
on its own.
But I think one thing to keep in mind here is yes, there is the Espionage component to
the people associate this was spying.
But keep in mind that this is a law that governs how sensitive information must be handled
and kind of putting in writing that you can't distribute it.
And so that's the portion of the law that is getting Trump in trouble here is that you
cannot retain and remove these documents from the setting in which they are meant to be
kept.
So where we're at now with the former president being indicted for a second time, Republicans
have just slammed what they say is Joe Biden's political persecution of his number one 2024
challenger.
Here's a video of Missouri Republican Josh Hawley on the matter.
And Laura, here's what I will say.
If the president in power can just jail his political opponents, which is what Joe Biden
is trying to do tonight, we don't have a republic anymore.
We don't have the rule of law.
We don't have the constitution.
Our constitution is built on the basic rule of law and due process.
And nobody should be in doubt of what's happening tonight.
Joe Biden and his cronies are trying to take out their chief political opponent.
This has never happened before in American history, Laura.
We are in dangerous, dangerous waters.
And it is because of Joe Biden.
And we also have Congressman Byron Donald's who tweeted, quote, on the day, members of
Congress learn from an FBI document linking, then vice president Joe Biden to receiving
$5 million from Burisma in a pay for play scheme.
Biden's DOJ announces another phony indictment of the leading candidate for the GOP presidential
nomination.
Biden's likely opponent and the former president, this mob-like justice system is turning
lady justice on its head and is the most significant threat to our democracy.
Stand with President Trump.
Meanwhile, CNN reports that today, President Biden is planning to go about his schedule
without waiting into the matter of Trump's indictment, a, quote, intentional demonstration
of calm and normalcy amid the continuing chaos of his predecessor.
At what point do you think Biden does weigh in on this indictment, if at all?
Yeah, well, so just to go back to the first question, in terms of some of the Republican
commentary on this and DOJ and FBI being politicized, I mean, I think we've heard two kind of
different lines from Republicans this week.
They've also been actively pursuing a probe into President Biden.
And after a briefing with the FBI on that matter this week, they were, you know, basically
commending the tip, commending the FBI, stressing the importance of this tip to the FBI.
But in this other matter, they've argued it's political.
Democrats have completely dismissed that.
And I think if you look at the kind of extent of the case here, it's not just pursuing Trump
because he had classified records.
There's more to these charges.
It's about a broader effort to retain the documents and refuse to turn them over.
When I think about Donald Trump's reaction here, not just initially to, okay, we know
that you have classified documents and they're at Mar-a-Lago, where we have a lot of foreign
folks coming in and out.
People with power, people we wouldn't probably want to have their hands on sensitive national
security information.
That's a concern.
But also his reaction to the legal process of, hey, we know you have these documents typically
in the case of Pence and Clinton.
They've said, okay, I'll turn them back over.
In the case of Trump, it seems as though he's really tried to hang on to them.
He's had people move documents around when he's heard.
They want to get the documents from him that are at Mar-a-Lago.
To me, it seems like this kind of comparison where we can say, all right, yes, Clinton
and Pence had documents.
That's kind of like taking a candy bar out of a convenience store.
With Trump, it's like he took a television.
And then moreover said, well, this isn't much different than if I had just used a credit
card.
I pay later anyway.
I'm still going to pay for it.
It's technically all fine.
That's really the comparison I see.
And then he's going to go write truth social tweets about it and brag about it.
In the eyes of the law, it seems to me that most people, when they act, they're going
to act that way after committing a crime.
Typically a judge gives them a harder sentence than when they have remorse and take accountability
and say, you know, I'm sorry, I'm going to do the legal process here.
How much do you think that is at play with this indictment?
How Trump has reacted to our legal process and system of justice?
Well, regardless, it really doesn't matter who takes or retains documents.
That's improper.
But the key distinction again, when we're looking at the fact that Pence and Biden had
documents, they actually notified the Justice Department that they found these records.
And when you look at the Trump case, you know, it started with archives.
They were the one that reached out and said, we believe you have presidential records.
It took several months to get them back.
An initial 15 boxes turned over included 184 classified records.
That's what began the referral to the Justice Department.
They repeatedly asked for the records.
They were unable to get them that resulted in a subpoena.
The compliance with the subpoena elicited another 38 classified records, but we've learned through
court filing sense that, you know, Trump's attorney who turned over those 38 documents
may have been misled as the additional records that were on the property.
And of course, the resulting search of Mar-a-Lago authorities found another 103 classified records.
And so, you know, it's not just about remorse.
It's about cooperating with authorities.
And it's also about ensuring that you're complying with the law and a key distinction for the
prosecution on an espionage act charge is showing the willful retention.
If you've turned over documents once you've been alerted that you have them, you're not
willfully retaining them.
Republicans have also alleged that the prosecutor here, Jack Smith, is perhaps politically tainted
because of his involvement in the IRS lowest learner scandal of targeting conservative
nonprofits, as well as his previous donations to Democrats.
Will that matter at all as this indictment moves forward?
You know, those are all issues that from attorneys are free to raise in court.
You were also asking about, you know, is this indictment political?
What do we think about them bringing these charges?
But at the end of the day, that's what the justice system is kind of designed to weigh
these claims, right?
There are going to be jurors who evaluate this in terms of the bigger picture of the evidence
that the Justice Department has assembled.
And they'll determine if they think, you know, a conviction is warranted.
Rebecca Bich, thank you so much for joining us and breaking this down.
Thank you so much for having me.
We really appreciate it.
We'll be back.
Reactions to former President Trump's indictment are rolling in the GOP primary challenger
and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis came to his fellow candidates' defense on Twitter,
writing, quote, the weaponization of federal law enforcement represents a mortal threat
to a free society.
We are, for years, witnessed an uneven application of the law depending upon political affiliation.
Senator Ron Johnson tweeted, remembering James Comey's exoneration of Hillary Clinton's
classified document obstruction saying, no reasonable prosecutor would bring such a case.
Correctable standard?
Journalist Michael Tracy pointed out, quote, everyone who was sentient from 2017 to 2021
knows if the Trump DOJ had indicted Barack Obama, Hillary Clinton, or Joe Biden for any
reason at all.
It doesn't matter the details.
It would have been wall to wall blaring that the country had disintegrated into apocalyptic
fascism.
The State Department inspector general, quote, credibly accused Hillary Clinton of violating
the Federal Records Act and flouting State Department policies after it came out that
she conducted government business exclusively over a private server she had secretly installed
in her house.
So interesting comparisons to be made there.
What do you make of this, Senator?
I see you have something.
Something cooking on my sleeve.
Well, look, I think the Biden comparison here is probably the most apt, particularly because
of Biden's inability to declassify the documents that he was found to have been storing both
in his homes in Delaware as well as his office in Washington, D.C. at the Penn Biden Center.
And some of these documents were from a time that he was a sender.
And senators don't even have the capability to take documents out of a skiff, let alone
declassify them.
So I just have a hard time squaring the idea that the real crime that Trump committed
was not giving the documents back immediately, especially considering the FBI and the DOJ
were in the process of negotiating the return of the documents.
And in fact, had told Trump that everything was fine at Mar-a-Lago so long as they put
an additional lock on the storage container where these documents were being held, then
all of a sudden they flipped a switch essentially, issued a subpoena, and then conducted this
raid.
It seems like the prosecution aspect of this kind of came out of nowhere when the lawyer
and Trump were seen to be cooperating.
Yeah, it seems to me there's a lot we don't know about what that negotiation was like.
Also I have a big question mark around why was there a negotiation at all?
Why wasn't it just here are the documents there in this box?
Of course I know where they are because it's very sensitive information and here you go.
The fact that this was a negotiation at all makes me a little concerned.
We don't hear about, okay, what was the negotiation for the documents to be given back by Biden
or by Penns.
It was, I will comply, I know what I have generally.
It wasn't, I have a treasure trove of hundreds of documents, which it seems to be the case
here that the volume of documents is a distinction and also just the fact that Trump has been
resistant to cooperate.
And so from what we know, there were documents moved after there was a request from the archives
that, hey, these are missing, we've got to get these back.
And we hear that Trump had them moved within Mar-a-Lago, which to me signals, was he trying
to hide them?
Was he trying to hang on to them?
I'm not sure.
It seems that there wasn't full cooperation here.
And that to me is I think why we see this indictment happening.
Seems to be comparing apples to apples if we were to say, well, other people had documents
as well that they shouldn't have had.
Seems to be apples to oranges.
I really think the analogy fits that with others it's like they took a candy bar out
of the store, right?
Not good, not supposed to steal.
Then they were like, hey, I think you accidentally grabbed that without paying, give it back.
And they were like, okay, here you go.
With Trump, it was like he took something of high value, far more documents, hundreds.
It's like taking a television and then you're like, hey, don't you have a television?
He kind of is like, get it if you can.
And then he says, well, I should have the television anyway.
So it would have been just like if I had paid with a credit card.
That's him saying, well, me taking them made them declassified.
It feels like we're comparing apples to oranges by comparing this case to others.
And it feels dangerous as well.
I just have a hard time believing that Biden was cooperating when he had these documents
for decades and then somehow found them in the midst of the Mar-a-Lago raid.
It's a CYA effort, right?
Because he knew that he had the documents, realized that the Justice Department was going
after Trump for exactly the same thing.
I got some of those in love.
And it was like, oh crap, I better go grab these documents and give them back.
I mean, come on.
Is that a cooperation, really?
And I think the thing that I'm having trouble squaring here too is that the president has
the authority under the Presidential Records Act to take whatever he wants in terms of
presidential records before he leaves office.
And that was apparently the process under what under which these documents were moved
to Mar-a-Lago in the first place.
And it's exactly the same authority that Clinton cited when he took national security-related
audio recordings and hid them in a sock drawer.
The Espionage Act was created and signed into law before the modern classification
system even existed.
So it's kind of stunning to me that this would even be applicable to the conversation that
we're talking about here.
If Trump can take the documents under the Presidential Records Act and is perfectly within
his authority to do so, then why is it suddenly a crime that he doesn't give them back at
the speed at which the National Archives requests them?
I think the main complicating factor here.
And we might see how much this is at play when it becomes public record when we see
this court case play out.
But Mar-a-Lago having so many folks visit from foreign countries, maybe our adversaries,
Trump having meetings with them, having the documents at Mar-a-Lago, where he's meeting
with foreign adversaries, I think is a huge factor at play here for why they're deciding
to indict him under the Espionage Act versus other charges, right?
Well, I would point out that Joe Biden had the documents in his garage that was unlocked,
that Hunter Biden, who has business deals with Ukraine, apparently receiving a million
dollars from a corrupt Romanian official, and sitting on the board of a Chinese energy
company and going in and out of that garage in his photograph, in fact, in the car next
to where the documents were sitting, seems like a pretty apt comparison.
I think we don't know what documents are had by either of these folks.
So we don't know if the documents that Biden had had nothing to do with China had nothing
to do with Ukraine.
We don't know what's in those documents.
With Trump, we know that there were hundreds of documents.
And we also know that Jared Kushner had many dealings with foreign adversaries and conducted
business abroad on many occasions.
So if we want to see an indictment of Hunter Biden for that and Jared Kushner, fine.
Like yeah, for sure.
But when we talk about the documents, having that many documents at a location where foreign
adversaries themselves are frequenting, that I think makes this.
The bigger national security concern than if it were in Trump's garage at his house,
where we don't have foreign adversaries visiting and staying all of the time.
It just seems convenient to me that the DOJ suddenly had an issue with the national security
concerns of the documents when they were at Mar-a-Lago for basically a year and a half
after Trump leaving office, right?
And apparently they didn't even notice that they didn't have them, the national archives
that is, until January of this past year.
So it's like, okay, if this was such a great threat, why wasn't there immediate action
to make sure that these documents were returned?
And why is it only happening at the same time that the Manhattan DA, Alvin Bragg, is indicting
Trump for this supposed falsification of business records related to Stormy Daniel?
And that's what causes this perception that this is a political prosecution.
I want to bring in some more details on the issue of the Espionage Act.
So journalists and former rising host Ryan Grimm tweeted, quote, good time to remind
conservatives that Daniel Ellsberg has been arguing for years that the Espionage Act is
unconstitutional.
It is an unconstitutional violation of the First Amendment.
If a government official mishandles classified information, they can be administratively punished,
fired, et cetera, but it is not a crime.
Meanwhile, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton told Donald Trump, tweeting, bringing
this back in light of recent news, get a limited edition but her emails hat and support
onward together, groups working to strengthen our democracy.
She loves a good cash grab, doesn't she?
Yeah, always.
Yeah, I'm not a big Clinton fan.
But I don't know what to make of this Ryan Grimm tweet.
I mean, it's a good time to point that out.
Yes, it's a good time to point out that presidents and elected officials are held to a different
standard than perhaps journalists that are whistleblowers.
That's a concern here, definitely.
And so I don't know what to make of this tweet from Ryan Grimm.
I think it is a good time to remind conservatives of Daniel Ellsberg, especially when they're
making this about, oh, Trump's being treated differently under the eyes of the law.
But being administratively punished or fired, et cetera, but it not being a crime, I don't
know.
I think this is an easy tweet for conservatives to see and say, oh, this is a good argument
for our side of things.
Why is Trump being indicted now?
Yeah, I mean, certainly.
And the Espionage Act being this World War I relic, that was basically intended to take
out commies, by the way, who were sharing things or saying things that were against the US
government.
It was basically used as a political tool in the first place and now being used against
a former president to punish him for taking records that under a more modern act, the
presidential records act he had the authority to take.
I think Ryan Grimm makes an important point here, and I'm sure that that will definitely
come up in either Trump's legal defense or in the Republican political defense of this
indictment.
Yeah, I mean, I think the Pentagon Papers were a great thing to make public information.
I think there's a lot of stuff that's kept from the public under the guise of this is
a national security concern.
But really, it's something that's in the public interest.
If you're supposed to be serving us in government and you're making bad decisions about why
we should intervene in the Vietnam War, we have no business being there.
Our Cold War agenda abroad was not something that the public was deeply aware of.
All of the United States covert operations in other countries, all of the proxy wars
we were involved in that we didn't find out about until years later.
And I think situations where we have the Pentagon Papers documents like this come out thanks
to whistleblowers.
I think those are good.
Donald Trump, however, having these documents, we don't know what they are.
It's really hard for us, as the public and the court of public opinion, to evaluate justice
in this case, right?
We know what the law is.
We know what's technically something being declassified.
We know there's a process here.
We know Trump probably isn't aware of all of the details in those documents.
He probably isn't even aware of what would be sensitive for certain individuals to get
their hands on.
So that's why I think the declassification process makes sense, because he can talk to
experts who can speak to those things before he decides to declassify them.
I think the main concern for me is who had access to these documents other than Donald
Trump.
If it's just Donald Trump looking at them, he saw them before he's seeing them again
now.
I mean, that's not a big deal for me.
It's just the sharing.
It's actually weird that we haven't had more leaks about what the documents specifically
were, because I feel like if they were really sensitive, national security related things,
you kind of have this catch-22, where it's like, can the media report on it?
But why aren't they if it's so bad?
Giving us a hint of what it actually is, because obviously the mainstream media would want
to leak details that would make Trump look bad and make this indictment look just.
But based on what we do know, a large chunk of these documents were related to the Crossfire
Hurricane probe, and Trump was supposedly hanging on to them in the event that the
Durham report dragged out longer or wasn't completed in time for his re-election run,
and he said that he wanted to declassify these and release these to the general public so
that they could see the errors that the FBI made in its investigation.
And the Durham report did confirm that the FBI had little to no evidence on which to
actually prompt Crossfire Hurricane, which was, of course, the investigation that accused
Trump of colluding with the Russian government in order to get elected in 2016.
So if it's the case that the vast majority of these hundreds of documents were related
to that investigation, then I don't have a problem with him having those or releasing
those at all.
Yeah, that would be fascinating.
If we had documents released ahead of this trial, that would be an interesting turn of
events.
Let's do it.
And we'll report on it here on Rising, but we've got more Rising after this.
Just hours after he was indicted on seven new counts related to the mishandling of
classified documents, former President Donald Trump has already parted ways with his legal
team.
Trump said in a statement on Truth Social,
"...for purposes of fighting the greatest witch hunt of all time, now moving to the
Florida courts, I will be represented by Todd Blanche and a firm to be named later.
I want to thank Jim Trusty and John Raleigh for their work, but they were up against a
very dishonest, corrupt, evil, and sick group of people, the likes of which
has not been seen before.
We will be announcing additional lawyers in the coming days.
When will Joe Biden be indicted for his many crimes against our nation?"
MAGA.
Trusty made the cable news rounds just last night in defense of his now former client.
Let's watch some of that.
I have this conversation with him.
He very quickly pivots to concern about the country.
You know, it's not a real selfish analysis.
This is a bad moment for our history.
This is our country turning the corner.
And as somebody that's been around criminal justice for over 30 years, I agree with him.
It's a Rubicon we shouldn't be crossing.
But doesn't the president, don't you believe in the principle that no person is above the
law?
If the president committed the same crime that someone else did, shouldn't he be charged?
No person is below the law.
That's really the issue here.
I mean, you've got these investigations in Delaware that are a thousand times more serious
by a sitting president who has authorized his DOJ to try to sink the candidacy of his
prime opposition while that guy has unsecured documents that he stole out of a skiff dozens
of years ago.
So look, you know, we're not talking about some sort of...
What are you talking about, sir?
What are you talking about?
That is a ridiculous statement.
There's this issue.
Nice try.
There's an issue that anyone that reads any newspapers would agree is a parallel track,
which is the Delaware document scandal of Joe Biden, where there's a special counsel,
a cop heard that's investigating it.
All right.
So what I make of this is basically Trump had some lawyers that were working for him, then
turns out this case is going to be held in Miami.
There was some stuff going on in D.C.
There were some rumors that the case would be in D.C.
And they're like, well, this is a logical point for us to no longer represent you, Donald
Trump.
It's been a really hard case to represent you in because the media is very hostile.
A lot of people have been hostile towards us.
For our mental health, we're going to not represent you.
It's not you, Donald Trump.
It's not the case.
It's us.
I mean, I don't know if you can, but Todd Blanche is also on the hook for the prosecution
in New York related to the Stormy Daniels case.
So Todd Blanche taking this on.
He's got his hands full.
Yeah, definitely.
There was a statement released from Jim Trusty and John Rally, where they said, this morning
we tendered our resignations as counsel to President Trump, and we will no longer represent
him on either the indicted case or the January 6 investigation.
It has been an honor to have spent the last year defending him.
And we know he will be vindicated in his battle.
Now that the case has been filed in Miami.
This is a logical moment for us to step aside.
But the January 6 investigation is not in Miami.
So I'm not sure that that explanation makes sense.
Right.
The documents being in Miami.
Okay.
But yeah, it does seem that the lawyers are like, well, the cases, you know, we're moving
around.
There's different cases in different states.
And so it's a logical point for us to step aside.
It's not that they couldn't practice in Miami.
It's not that they could not represent him.
It's just we're going to stop now and use this geography of where this new case regarding
the Mar-a-Lago documents is being taken.
We're just going to step aside.
Let someone else take over here.
Yeah, it does seem that way.
And Trusty was Trump's lawyer when the search warrant was first executed in Florida.
He was also involved in the special master situation with Eileen Cannon in the 11th circuit.
So yeah, the explanation seems a little convenient, but we do know that Trump goes
through lawyers pretty quickly.
So I guess it's not super surprising either.
Yeah, he goes through lawyers like I go through socks.
And that was absolutely the case in his last few months in office as well.
And there were a lot of announcements like this where it's, you know, I have new legal
representation now.
And so they're pretty used to this.
They know that people in the media, like us, are going to talk about it and say nobody
wants to represent this guy because it's a literal nightmare.
